* The speaker is discussing a project related to speech recognition and is considering whether to hold off on a task until better results are obtained.
* The speaker mentions that the current results are not bad, even though there are still some errors.
* The speaker also mentions that other systems are doing things between roughly a third and half of the errors being eliminated, and that the best results are in the range of roughly a third to two-thirds of the errors being eliminated.
* The speaker mentions that they don't know who had the best result on the development set, but that the two systems proposed by a combination of French Telecom and Alcatel did well.
* The speaker also mentions that they haven't seen final results for the evaluation set yet.
* The speaker mentions that the main thing that the two systems used was spectral subtraction, but there were also some modifications to the cepstral parameters.
* The speaker also mentions that they think that the methods they are using can reduce the error rate from around 9% to around 6%.
* The speaker also mentions that they think that one of the things that Hynek was talking about was understanding what was in the other good proposals and trying to see if what should ultimately be proposed is some combination of things.
* The speaker also mentions that they think that the best system so far was around 50% on the development set, and that the best result of any system was around 54%.
* The speaker also mentions that there was less of a huge range of results in Aurora one compared to this project.
* The speaker also mentions that the worst system on the development set still reduced the error rate by around 33%.
* The speaker also mentions that they think that it is a good time to look at what's really going on and see if there's a way to combine the best ideas while not blowing up the amount of resources used.

* The speaker is discussing a test of speech recognition systems
* The test had a "reduction in word error rate" as a key point
* The systems being tested had varying levels of error reduction, with some systems performing much better than others
* The worst performing system still reduced error rate by 33% in the development set
* The speaker suggests that it may be a good idea to look at the best ideas from the systems that performed well and combine them while also being mindful of resource usage
* The speaker mentions that the two best performing systems were from a combination of French Telecom and Alcatel and used spectral subtraction and cepstral mean subtraction
* The speaker also mentions that some other systems used spectral subtraction and cepstral mean subtraction but with different approaches to adapting the mean during speech and silence.

* The speaker is discussing a project related to speech recognition and is considering ways to improve the accuracy of the system.
* They mention that one approach is to use filters and add them to the server side of the system.
* They also mention that it would be ideal to have a combination of filters and other methods to improve the accuracy of the system.
* The speaker mentions that the process of creating a standard for speech recognition has been ongoing for some time and people may want to declare a standard despite not knowing enough yet.
* The speaker also mentions that standards can be optional and that it is not final if a standard is declared.
* The speaker is interested in hearing the thoughts of the other person about where to go from here and if they should back off from the project and take their time to explore the speech recognition process.
* The other person mentions that they will look at the speech data from the databases and explore the causes of the degradation in accuracy.
* They also mention that most of the errors are within phoneme classes and that improving recognition of phoneme classes could be an important step in improving the accuracy of the system.
* The speaker mentions that even with the best cases, some of the numbers are still horrible and that improving the recognition of phoneme classes could be a simpler and more important problem.
* The speaker also mentions that they are considering using filters to improve the accuracy of the system.
* The other person mentions that they are also considering the well-matched German and Danish cases and that the kind of numbers they are getting are about 8-9% error per digit which is obviously not usable.

* The speaker is discussing the quality of speech recognition in noisy environments with a colleague.
* The colleague suggests taking a closer look at the speech data to see where the errors are occurring and how they differ in clean and noisy speech.
* The speaker agrees that this could be a simpler and more effective approach than rushing to try new methods.
* The colleague also notes that the recognition of phoneme classes, rather than individual phonemes, could be an important factor in improving speech recognition in noisy environments.
* The speaker agrees and suggests that looking at the confusion matrices of speech recognition in noisy environments could provide valuable insights.
* The colleague also mentions that the best cases of speech recognition in noisy environments are still not very good and that the numbers they are getting are around 8-9% error per digit.
* The speaker notes that this is not usable and that speech recognition in noisy environments is still a challenging problem.
* The colleague also mentions that the speech database they are using is realistic and that the training is done on different conditions and microphones.
* The speaker agrees and suggests that if they only used the close microphones, the results should be much better.
* The colleague also mentions that the mismatched conditions, such as different driving conditions, also affect the speech recognition results.
* The speaker nods and agrees with the colleague's points.
